(continues on next page)

4493661/4408955/4520562.title: The Local Roads
4493661/4408955/4520562.text:
The names of the local roads are Dooen road, Roughan road,  Drimnaught road, Bomany road,  Crieve road, Cark road, and the main road in which all the traffic runs on. These roads were made about a hundred years ago. Some of the roads were made for relief work during the Famine period.The men worked for pay. They got two pounds four shillings weekly. Some of these roads are not used for traffic because they are not in good enough repair for traffic to go on. There are no old paths in which I can go home from school but there is a by way off from the main road which I can go home. This road is repaired every year by sand and stones. It is not repaired in the same way as the main road. The main
(continues on next page)

4493664/4409076/4521924.title: Local Roads
4493664/4409076/4521924.text:
There are nine roads leading from the town of Ramelton to other parts of Donegal.The Lough Side Road is situated beside Lough Swilly. Some people call it the Hospital Road because it leads out to the Hospital.The Killycreen Road leads out to the townland of Killycreen.The New Mill Road is short, it ends in the downland of New Mill.The Ardrummond Road goes as far as the townland of Ardrummond.The Letterkenny Road is eight miles in length,
(continues on next page)

4493664/4409126/4521989.title: The Bught Road
4493664/4409126/4521989.text: The Bught Road is a road leading from Ramelton in the Co. Donegal towards the East side. On leaving Ramelton we pass the Creamery on the left hand side, and further on we pass Doctor Boyle's and the Dispensary. About one hundred yards further on the Bught Road starts, and it is about one mile in length.The name Bught means a Bay or a Bight. It gets its name because there is an inlet of Lough Swilly which comes in at that place. It is a beautiful place when the tide is full.

4493690/4411447/4523621.title: Bóithre an Cheantair
4493690/4411447/4523621.text: Casan na bealach mór an t-ainm a bheireann na daoine ortha. I n-aimsir an droch-shaoghail a rinneadh cuid aca. Tá a lán bóithre úra sa cheantar. Tá siad i n-úsaid go fóill. Ta sé é blaidhna  [?] rinneadh iad. Rinneadh bóithre sa parróiste i n-aimsir an droch-shaoghail. Chá bíodh páig [?] ar bith aca, ag obair ar a gcuid a bhíodh siad. Cá bhíodh mná ar bith ag obair ar na bealtaí móra sá ceanntar.Cá rabh mé abálta eolas ar bith a fháfhail acht an píosa sin a d'innis mó athair damh.

4493685/4410516/4524606.title: Local Transport in the Late Nineteenth Century
4493685/4410516/4524606.text: Transport is a very easy matter nowadays. Seventy years  ago when shopkeepers in Fanad wanted goods they had a very hard job to get them. When they had a load of eggs gathered in they packed them in boxes with straw. They loaded their carts and started off to Rathmullan at midnight. When arrived at Rathmullan they put on a small boat and started for Fahan. At Fahan another cart was hired to go to Derry. Another night was spent in Derry before starting home. The Carts were again loaded with goods and they started home again boats for hiring were as plenty then as carries nowadays.

4493685/4410572/4524675.title: Old Rights of Way (Local)
4493685/4410572/4524675.text: There is a right of way from the Roughan to Tamney. One from Aughadreena to Ballydeskin. One from Aughadreena to Rathgory. One from Croghan to Massmount. One from Lagboy to Corry. One from Lagboy to Cashelprehan. One from Ballykinard to Rossnakill. One from Aughadreena to Ballymagowan. One from the Planting to Greenfort. One from Corry to Murrin. One from Aughadaughly to Gortnacor. One from Duntinney to Starmount. One from Duntinney to Gortnacor. One from Ballyshanagh to Drumfad. One from the Roughan to Ballymagacy hill. One from Tamney to Croaghan. One from Lagboy to Gortnacor.

4493693/4411589/4525196.title: Roads
4493693/4411589/4525196.text: The present main road from Stranorlar to Glenties passing on the south side of the River Finn is a comparatively new road. The new road in a good many places follows the line of the old road. The old road would appear to have gone more by the hills, some of it is still used, but other tracks are plain to be seen as, for example the part which passes through Glenmore estate, and comes out again on Meenagrave hill and continues until it joins the present Altnapaste road. Where there was once a prosperous village which carried on a weaving industry.

4493636/4406262/4525621.title: Seanchas i dtaobh na hAimsire
4493636/4406262/4525621.text:
(continued from previous page)
When the rocks look bright after a shower denotes thunder.Wind. Ducks quacking loudly denote wind.A copper coloured sky means a gale of wind.Before (S) wind comes, the cat begins to scrape, the geese fly and the clouds begin to float along like ships.When geese make a great noise with their wings a storm or gale is approaching.



There is a shortcut leading from Faugher to Parkmore and it is a public one. About forty years ago there was only a path going to Parkmore. People with horse and carts had to cross the Marblehill strand. Patrick Gallagher, Faugher, Ballymore. Story told by Ellen Gallagher, Faugher.In Glassan there is a nearway through a hill called "the Binn". In Carnamaddy there is a road which was lately made, this road leads to Lough na Ball. In Rooskey there is a road which leads up to the bog and it is called Meenadrain.
(continues on next page)

4493636/4406263/4525624.title: Bóithre an Cheantair
4493636/4406263/4525624.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



Some of the roads in this parish are as follows. The road from the tunnel to Ard's House.The real avenue is seven miles long but it contains several short cuts and the distance can be accomplished in about an hour. This road was made by the orders of one of the Stuart family of Ards. Other paths which branch off this road are "Smith's Road", "Wasson's Road", and James Ferry's Road. These roads were made about eighty years ago.Another road is the Knocknafaugher Road which runs through the townland of Knocknafaugher into the main road at the Gap of the Moss about three miles from Dunfanaghy.The Graveyard Road which runs from near Dunfanaghy through Kill to the Clondahorky Graveyard and then branches off to the road which runs from Dunfanaghy to Roshine.The Marblehill Road branches off the main road at Faugher School and runs through Marbelhill and Parkmore to meet the new Breaghy and Parkmore Road.The Lough Road starts at the Cross Roads at Mc Elhiney's Garage and terminates at
(continues on next page)

4493636/4406264/4525658.title: Bóithre an Cheantair
4493636/4406264/4525658.text:
(continued from previous page)
Friel's, Sandhill, Dunfanaghy.There is a path called the "Cob Road" in the townland of Rockhill in the land which belongs to Robert Algeo. This path is a short-cut to Port-na-blagh, and it is not much in use now-a-days. It was made during the Famine and the payment the workers got was potatoes called "Cobs".The "shore road" leading to Port-na-blagh was also made during the Famine period.



This is a list of the roads in this parish.The Cob Road from Rockhill to Port-na-blagh.The new road from Rockhill to Marblehill.The Sessiaghlough Road which runs along the lough.The Dundredian Road from Faugher to Marblehill and the Marblehill Road.The "Cob Road" got its name because they used to cart potatoes along it to the pier at Port-na-blagh. The pier at Port-na-blagh was built during the Famine days. The pay was eight pence a day or a bag of meal.
(continues on next page)

4493636/4406265/4525665.title: Bóithre an Cheantair
4493636/4406265/4525665.text:
(continued from previous page)
Lady Isopel Stuart got the tunnel built at Ballymore because she did not want to go to the same road to church as her tenants, so she got the Tunnel Road built for herself. She used it only about twelve times. The pay was six pence a day.



Lag na gCorp is an old path in Purt Hill. Long ago when there were no roads atall, when a person would die his corpse used to be brought down by this path to bury it at at Clondahorkey. There are also stones along this path on which the corpse would be left, while the people would rest who were carrying it, this is how it got its name



During the famine the road from Dunfanaghy to Port-na-Blagh was made and the pier at Port-na-Blagh was also made. The wage for a man was 8d a day.At the time of the famine people were allowed no more than 2 stones of meal for a week.
(continues on next page)

4493636/4406265/4525670.title: Bóithre an Cheantair
4493636/4406265/4525670.text:
(continued from previous page)

4493636/4406266/4525672.text:
(continued from previous page)
The demesne wall at Ards was built during the famine days, and for the work a man was allowed 4d a day.Before the road from Dunfanaghy to Port-na-Blagh was made the people used the old road outside Dunfanaghy which was once the main road to Creeslough and Letterkenny. It is called the old road because it is so long in existence.



There is an old road going through Dundredian and Lower Faugher and from that on to the main road. It was made about seventy years ago. It is not in use now as there is a new road made. Farmers use it still for carting on. The wages were small that time about 10d a day. There is another old road branching off the Breaghy road leading to a farmer's house. There is an old road running from Marblehill to Cloonmass. There is a path running across fields from Parkmore to Marblehill road. There is another path from Parkmore to Breaghy Hill. Another path goes from Breaghy to Port-na-Blagh. There is
(continues on next page)

4493636/4406267/4525673.title: Bóithre an Cheantair
4493636/4406267/4525673.text:
(continued from previous page)
a path through the hill from Faugher to Knocknafaugher.



Before the Breaghy Road was made the people would go a near way to Dunfanaghy and to the shops. There is a cross roads at Drimnaraw. About forty years ago the people used to cross the Marblehill strand and they would have to watch for the tide.



There is a Mass rock in Jim Algeo's field Faugher. There is a Mass rock in the field of James Friel, Sandhill, a townland convenient to Dunfanaghy.



One time during the Penal Laws a priest was being hunted in Ballymore. A Protestant man named Wilkinson took him in and hid him in a meal barrel. During the night English soldiers came to search for him. They asked
(continues on next page)

(continued from previous page)

4493689/4411010/4526979.title: Cistí Óir i bhFolach
4493689/4411010/4526979.text: Tá cistí óir i dtaisce ag Tor-a-Cuillin i bhFál Naois agus do réir an t-seachuis na Loclannaigh a chuir ann é ins an deicheamhadh aois nuair a bhí siad ag troid leis na h-Éireannaigh.Rinneadh iarraid é a fhágháil san seactadh aois déagh. Tháinig cúigh fear anios as Glinsc oidhche amháin agus thoisigh siad ag obair san áit ach chan fhuair siad é. Nuair a fuair na daoine sin bás bhí eagla ar na daoine óga buint dó.Ní 'fhuair duine ar bith ór a bhí i dtaisce riamh ins an cheanntar seo ach do réir an t-seanchuis tá na "daoine maithe" ag cosaint air agus níor bhuin duine ar bith leis go dhí an lá indiú.

4493720/4414071/4527769.title: Béaloideas - Casán na mBráthair
4493720/4414071/4527769.text: Casán na mBráthair is a path which led from the townland of Ballykerrogan in Glenfin, I [?] over the Barnes mountains in the direction of Donegal town. It is believed that the Monks of Donegal Abbey used it and it is from then it got its name. Loc […] is in the Barnes mountains also it is believed that there are jewels at the bottom of that lake. Hence its name Belshade from mod [?] --a jewel.

4493723/4414215/4527909.title: Local Roads
4493723/4414215/4527909.text:
There are two principal roads in this district, both lead from Lifford to Derry. The main road from Lifford divides in two parts at Rossgier. One runs along the lowland along the River Foyle and it is called the Clonleigh Road. The other runs along higher land through Cavan, Drumleen, and Craighadoes. These two roads meet near St Johnston.The Clonleigh Road is the straight road from Lifford to Derry. In by gone days the Clonleigh Road was liable to flood. So the mail car always went the other way.After the siege of Derry, King James fell back on the Clonleigh Road. Mongavelin Castle is near to the Clonleigh Road and it was held for King James. James and his army marched on towards Ballindrait. It is said James took his dinner under an oak tree at Cavanacor.A story is told about an old man who was breaking stones along the Clonleigh Road when King James was passing. He did not know the King and he asked "who won the fight at  Derry"  James answered "It does not matter to you keep on at your
(continues on next page)

4493724/4414306/4528188.title: Composition - The Star of Gortin
4493724/4414306/4528188.text: I heard the following story about the Star of Gortin from Mr Francis Mongan.  It is a big white stone in Mr Lindsay's field in the townland of Gortin.  The people say there is a chief buired under it.  It is called the Star of Gortin because no matter how dark the night is it can be seen shining for a long distance from you.  It is about one hundred yards from the side of the road on the left hand side.  The road I mean is the road leading from Raphoe to Clady.

4493706/4412819/4528469.title: Ancient Roads - An Old Bridle Path
4493706/4412819/4528469.text:
An old bridle road or path, stretching almost due north & south, down the side of Curraghamongan to a ford in the River Finn and continuing due south on the Dooish side of the river, supposed to stretch from Letterkenny to Donegal & Ballyshannon through Barnesmore. Traces (in the form of double fences or "ditches") remained until quite recently when the stones of which they were formed were removed for road metal. On the Curraghamongan side a single straight stone wall, broken in places, is supposed to mark its course. The recently removed "double-ditch" was on the farm
(continues on next page)

4493736/4415186/4529011.title: The Coach Road
4493736/4415186/4529011.text: On Mr Rankin's farm the Cloon Carrigans there is a field called the Coach Road   It is on the left hand side of the road between the Five Cross Roads and Boak's Corner   This is  a part of the old stage coach road that ran from Derry to DublinOn Mr Stevenson's farm Derrymore Carrigans there is a part of the same road in very good condition   It is on the of the hill to north of Derrymore farm  house and is known as The GlenExcepting that it is almost overgrown with bushes it is practically the same as when the coaches ran on itWritten byEmily Wray DerrymoreCarrigans20th July 1938

4493736/4415202/4529051.title: Local Roads
4493736/4415202/4529051.text: Monreagh School townland of Tonagh Parish of Taughboyne barony of North Raphoe lies between two roads leading from St Johnston to Newtowncunningham one road goes via Five Cross Roads and Argony Pipe the other through the village of Taughboyne. There are no very old roads with the exception of the remnants of the old Coach Road already mentioned, There is a road leading from Taughboyne to Five Cross roads via Taughboyne Rectory called  The long Ballet Lane but I cannot discover origin of name

4493653/4407782/4529092.title: Our Local Estate
4493653/4407782/4529092.text:
Landlord - Stewart of Ards - "Good".Agent - Murphy - "Good".Bailiffs - Robert Kennedy, Cuolboy, Letterkenny - "Good."John McDermott, Calhame, Letterkenny - Bad - nick-named "cut-bag".James Wasson, Dunfanaghy - "Very bad."



The "Greers" of Killyclug, Letterkenny - mother and 3 daughters evicted. The mother's name in Rent book was Mrs. Greer. She could not be prosecuted without the Christian name. On one occasion, her eldest daughter was asked by the Agent, for her mother's Christian name. She said that the neighbours always respected her mother so much that she never was called anything but "Mrs. Greer." Asked for her own Christian name, she replied "Mary Jane" In this name her mother was prosecuted and this led to the eviction, as unfortunately, it so happened that "Mary Jane" was the mother's name too.The eviction followed shortly afterwards, and these Greers went to Derry.

4493733/4415066/4529460.title: Local Roads
4493733/4415066/4529460.text: In the year eighteen hundred and forty seven the main road from Derry to Letterkenny was widened and its route was changed in places to make it more level and at other places the hills were cut to make it more level also.The road from Ray to Manorcunningham was made round by the edge of the village to avoid the Knowes which is very steep. There was also a new road made from Dromore to Pluck. The old road is still to be seen crossing over Magherbuoy hill.The portion from the Veagh to Drumbarnet was also newly made. The old road still runs down through Sharron.There was also a road made from magheramore to Manorcunningham about forty years ago, and there was a new bridge built there also.About ten years ago there was a new road made from Ray to Rossbracken and a concrete bride built over Kenaghan River.

4493746/4415768/4530061.title: Local Roads
4493746/4415768/4530061.text: The names of the local roads I know are:- "The Moss Road" which leads from the foot of Leitrim lane to the Crossroads. "Bogay Road" which leads from Bogay to the main road. "Mason's Road" which leads from "The Hill Road" to a bridge and there are three roads meet together. I don't know when they were made. The roads are very old in my district. The roads are still used. There are no local accounts as to when they were made. I do not know if roads were made in my district as a relief work during the famine period. There are no mountain passes in my district. I do not know if the rivers were crossed by means of fords at shallow places before bridges were made in my district. Sometimes people gather at the crossroads for playing.There are no heaps of stones or monuments to the dead along any road in my district. There are no mass paths.

4493746/4415770/4530066.title: Local Roads
4493746/4415770/4530066.text: These are the names of some of the local roads The Eddie Corner" "Mickey's Brae" "Pound Brae", "The Hill Road" and the "Back Road". The road that's called Mickey's Brae leads from Derry to Newtowncunningham. The road that's called the Pound Brae leads from the Letterkenny road to Bridgend, and the Back Road leads from the Letterkenny road meet the Pound Brae. These roads are very old. They are still used. The locals do not know when these roads were made. There is a bye road in my district called the Ball Boe. At crossroads people gather to play cards and to pitch pennies.

4493746/4415771/4530067.title: Local Roads
4493746/4415771/4530067.text: These are the local roads round my district:- The Laganaduff Road. "The Moss Road" "Kildrum Road" "Imilick Road", and "The Basin Road". The "Laganduff Road" leads from the main road to another road which leads to Carrigan's and St. Johnston. The Moss Road leads from the main road to another main road which leads to Carrigan's and St. Johnstone. The Kildrum Road leads from the main road to another main road which leads to Carrigans and St. Johnstone. The Imilick Road leads from the main road to the main road which leads to Carrigans and St. Johnstone. The Basin Road leads to Derry. These roads were in the last century. These roads are very old. They are still used. I don't know about these roads during the Famine period.

4493746/4415772/4530068.title: Local Roads
4493746/4415772/4530068.text:
The names of the roads in our district are: - the 'Cloon Road and the 'Garshuey Road'. The Cloon Road leads from the Garshuey Road to the Monglass Road. The Garshuey Road leads from the Cloon Road to the Kildrum Road. They are very old roads, in our district. They are not used.They pitch pennies at Cross - roads.



The Moss Road, Back Road and the Pound Brae lead into the Main Road. The Back Road is very old. I do not know when they were made. They are used yet. There are no accounts as to when they were made. There were no bridges at the time. They went to straight till they came to the road. There were Mass[?] paths. The people played cards at Cross - roads.
(continues on next page)

4493746/4415772/4530069.title: Local Roads
4493746/4415772/4530069.text:
The names of the roads in our district are: - the 'Cloon Road and the 'Garshuey Road'. The Cloon Road leads from the Garshuey Road to the Monglass Road. The Garshuey Road leads from the Cloon Road to the Kildrum Road. They are very old roads, in our district. They are not used.They pitch pennies at Cross - roads.



The Moss Road, Back Road and the Pound Brae lead into the Main Road. The Back Road is very old. I do not know when they were made. They are used yet. There are no accounts as to when they were made. There were no bridges at the time. They went to straight till they came to the road. There were Mass[?] paths. The people played cards at Cross - roads.
(continues on next page)

4493746/4415773/4530070.title: Local Roads
4493746/4415773/4530070.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



The name so roads in my district are: "The Hill Road" leadsd from the Pound Brae to Bridgend. "The Back road leads from Letterkenny Road area and meets the Pound Brae. These roads are very old. They are still used. There are no accounts as to who made these roads or when they were made.

4493752/4416983/4530575.title: Clothes Made Locally
4493752/4416983/4530575.text:
(continued from previous page)
spin many of them knit socks and stockings and some knits jumpers with it.



There are many roads in this district leading in every direction especially to the main roads. These are the names of some of the local roads, moss road, slab road, farland road, rusk road, Glebe road, Ballymoney road, Porterstown lane, Grange lane and stephen's lane. The moss road leads to the main road. The slab road is a nearcut to Newtowncunningham. The farland road leads to the shore. The Glebe roads leads to Toullette. The Ballymoney roads leads through the townland of Ballymoney.
(continues on next page)

4493753/4416635/4530750.title: Local Roads
4493753/4416635/4530750.text: There is a road leading from Durnin's to the Fort called the Grange road. There is a road leading from Baylett to Mill Bay called the Castle Quarter road. There is a road leading from the bridge to Carnaghan called the Glen road. There is a road leading from Carnaghan to Castle Quarter called the Dungeon road. There is a road leading from the Bank End to Baylett called the Shore road.

4493753/4416640/4530770.title: Local Roads
4493753/4416640/4530770.text: The Barrack Brae is the name of a road leads from Inch school to the crossroads at Mr Durnin's house. This road is about  fifty six years old and is still in use. The crossroads is situated in the Town land of Carricknee. The lower roads leads from the bridge to the Buncranna road. Mass Path's. One from the Glack to the Church and another from Naylett to the Church. The Strahack road leads from the Crossroads at Inch Post Office.

4493750/4416394/4530879.title: Famine
4493750/4416394/4530879.text:
(continued from previous page)
The Government had a relief work for the men. They made drains in mossy ground and roads. Our new main road was made by them. They were paid sixpence per day. After the Famine the Government sent round the Crowbar Brigades to put the people out of their houses. They were so called because they carried crowbars to tumble the houses. They gave people money to go to America to get rid of them.



The main road from Derry to Buncrana is a first class road. Off it branch several small roads. The first is the Inch road. It is called so because it leads to Inch island. The embankment which joins Inch with the main - land was built by Wagstaff and Brassy. Before it was made the sea at high tide went up as far as
(continues on next page)

4493751/4416507/4530991.title: Local Roads
4493751/4416507/4530991.text: There is an old road which runs along the foot of scalp mountains  - it leads to Buncrana, in olden times it was only a path for people or cattle  - further on there is an old road which runs through a place known as Grannies Gap and it was made in the year of the Famine - the work was done by people whose pay was 1s 6d per week and fed on charity meal and their gaffer was a Woman - her name was Miss Law - it runs through an old town called Budooey and Mullinaughy quarries at he present date where the people had to wade through the river with their horses and cartsAt the corner of this road there was a man murdered whoes name was Rush and a pile of stones   were gathered in by passers and as they threw in the stones, they were suppose to say Kill Rush(?)Maureen McColganSappagh

4493755/4416812/4531028.title: Old Roads
4493755/4416812/4531028.text:
13 Meiteam 1938Long ago the old people went from place to place on different roads which we walk on now. These roads are seldom used now and have different names from what they had. Pillar Park which runs from "Wilson's Bridge" up the brae to the end of the Urban beside Lindsay's was at one time called "Eacy Raggins brae" because long ago there there, a woman beside the brace called Eacy Raggin and one day she fell in to a little stream which runs on the right hand side of the the road and was drowned.People who wanted to go to Derry many years ago
(continues on next page)

4493755/4416858/4531056.title: The Local Roads
4493755/4416858/4531056.text: The local roadsThe roads leading into Buncrana are the old road, the new road, and Cockhill road. The old road was the principal road to Co Derry before the new road was built, though it got the name New road, it was built about eighty years, both roads are still used for traffic. The wages paid in those days were from sixpence to a shilling a day. There are no old paths or by roads in the school district. Mamore pass would be a near cut for people going to Carndonagh from Desertegney. There is a cairn of stones at Mamore pass for the people passing used to put a stone on the cairn when they were passing. People often go there to pray as there is a well there is a well beside it.

4493755/4416859/4531058.title: The Local Roads
4493755/4416859/4531058.text: About two hundred years ago the main road from Buncrana to Dublin was from Catair O's Castle which is a half-mile out side the town the north . This road led over Fahan Hill past the barracks and joined the present Derry  road  between Burnfoot and Derry . It was then called the Mail Car road to  Dublin . On a clear day this road can be traced on the side of the hill .There is a graveyard supposed to be on that road somewhere about the Moyle.

4493755/4416860/4531059.title: The Local Roads
4493755/4416860/4531059.text: "The Local Roads"The "old road" leading from Ballymacarry National School to the mill bridge is so called because it was the first main road leading into Buncrana. It was constructed in eighteen forty seven and forty eight. The road leading from Castle Bridge to LIsnakelly was made eatly in eighteen hundred. It was the main road to Clonmany and Carndonagh the road leading past the "Round Knowe" lead from the town to the "Illies" this road was known as the whinny road. Castle Avenue was known as the Gubbuck Lane.

4493766/4418057/4531819.title: The Local Roads
4493766/4418057/4531819.text: There are many roads in this district, some large and some small.The chief road is the main road from Derry to Mioville, this road runs through Muff. The road is fairly wide and has a tarred surface. This is not an old road as it was made over sixty years ago. There is a telegraph line from Derry to Moville along this road.The old Country Road that was used before the new one was made from Derry to Moville is still used, it is the one that my father uses to come from the main road to our house. It goes on past the front of our house through the glen and over behind The Grove and over through the Mitchelstown and past an old inn called "The Cutt". It went over a short distance and turned down to where the main road is now. The bridge in the glen where the road went over is now broken down. The old inn is still to be seen only it is rebuilt. There was an old iron ring fastened to the wall where the house used to be tied and I think it is still there.Jerry McConnell 11th March 1938Ardmore, Muff. Co. Donegal.

4493767/4418140/4533758.title: Local Roads
4493767/4418140/4533758.text:
Written by Susan Doherty, Umbally, Ture P.O.“Local Roads”The roads of this district get their names from where they lead to. There is a road leading from the main road straight up to the hill . It is called the new line until it reaches the town land of Aught . It is then called the Aught road, and in the town land of Glackmore it is called the Glackmore road. No one remembers this road being made . It is a very useful road and a lot of carts are seen on it. Many loads of turf are carted down that road from the hill. As well as in the summer, turf are carted all year for selling. From this road many lanes and other roads branch off. Such as the road leading to the school, known as the Gortin road. On the road leading to Clunelly each division is known by the townland it passes through. There is a part of that road between Meedinmore and Umbally called the moss road, because a moss lies on one side of it. At Meedinmore there are four roads , one leading to the main road another to the hill, another to Clunelly and the fourth to the Aught road. The one leading to the hill is known as the Spinh. These four roads form a cross road , where the men gathered long ago. It is not a gathering place nowadays.
(continues on next page)

4493768/4418247/4533919.title: (no title)
4493768/4418247/4533919.text:
The road from Derry passes through Muff barrow keel White Castle, Red Castle, and Castle Kerry to Movill.A road runs from Quigley's Point through Glen togher to Carndonagh.  Then from Carndonagh to Malin head.There is a road from Derry to Letter Kenny to Buncranna.There is a road from Derry to Lifford and Straban.On all these roads buses, Motor-Lorries Cars, and bicycles are to be seen.Lorries carry goods such as coal, timber, iron, steel, meal, flour, corn butter and eggs.Buses carry passengers from town to town and from place to place. Numbers of cars are to be seen on the roads.Lots of people are to be seen with bicycles on the roads.From these main roads a
(continues on next page)

4493768/4418319/4534049.title: (no title)
4493768/4418319/4534049.text: The first steam engine that was made in Ireland was made by Tomas Lynch of Carry in County Donegal.He showed her in London and drove her in the streets of London The government wanted to buy his patent for a large sum of money. But he would not accept the offer.So the government taxed him very heavyly for his patent. He paid the taxes for a few years and then he was not able.And So the government got it for nothing and improved on it.He went astray in the mind and died in the Asylum and his patent is still running.

4493769/4418398/4534437.title: The Local Roads
4493769/4418398/4534437.text: There is a road which leads from Iskaheen Chapel, Parish of Muff, Co Donegal, out to the main road at the village of Muff, it is called the Ardmore road because it leads through the Townland of Ardmore. There is another road leads from Carnamoyle out over the hill into Buncrana, it is called the Gap road, because it goes through a gap in the hill. It is mostly used for bringing the people's turf from the hill, this gap itself is called Grannies Gap, because it runs through Giant's hills.

4493769/4418399/4534438.title: The Local Roads
4493769/4418399/4534438.text: The names of some of the local roads in our district are the main road which leads from the village of Muff, Co Donegal, to the village of Burnfoot, Co Donegal. Another road is called the Gap road. It leads from the main road through a gap in the hill, called Grannie's Gap to Burnorand, Co Donegal. This Gap is called Grannie's Gap around here, because it runs through Grant's hills. Another one is the Iskaheen road, which leads from Iskaheen Chapel to the main road at Ture, Co Donegal. It was made in the Penal times, and it was made through Iskaheen burying ground.

4493712/4413422/4534767.title: Local Roads
4493712/4413422/4534767.text:
Roads are quite common in this district. These are the names of the roads of my district – Ballygonigan road, Drumurphy road, Tievebrack road, Flow road, […] road, Cornaseask road, Dungorman road, Caterson’s rpad. Teernisk road, New road, Belalt road, Meenlougher road, and Cornabrog road.The Ballygonigan road begins at Joe Geary’s corner of Ballybun and goes to Sam Taylor’s shop of Carnadore.The Tievebrack road runs from the Black Burn bridge, which it the separation between Tievebrack and Ballybun, to the Belalt road.The Flow Road begins at the four cross roads in Egaltybane and goes to Maggie Mc Laughlins of TievebrackThe Ballybun road begins at the Black Burn bridge and finishes at the broad road at the foot of Johny Kelly’s hill of Ballybun.The Cornaseask road begins at John Gallaghers of Meenlougher
(continues on next page)

4493783/4420087/4535875.title: Local Roads
4493783/4420087/4535875.text:
Local Roads.There is a road beginning at the bottom of Shrove. It leads to the mountain. It is called the Shrove Hill Road. It is believed to have been made in the year of the famine 1846. There is another road leading from the lower road to the upper road. It was made about one hundred and fifty years ago about the year 1887. There is another road beginning in Shrove which leads to the mountain . It was made 1892. a road begins in Carrowtrasna which leads to the mountain. It was made by Charlie Hernan, Carrowtrasna and his brother and father John and Denis Hernan in the year 1877. There is a very old road leading from Charlie Hernans house to Leveraug. It was made by John Farren in the year 1845. It is used yet. There is a mass-path leading from Pipper Hill to Ballybrack Chapel. It is still used by the people of the district. There is another mass-path beginning at Inishowen Head and ends at Ballymacarter. A mass-path leading from Glenagivney across the mountain to the chapel in Ballinacrae it is still used. The low road leads from Shrove to Moville. This road was made
(continues on next page)

4493774/4419110/4536097.title: Herbs
4493774/4419110/4536097.text:
(continued from previous page)
stalks are thrown out. In the morning everyone in the house gets two glasses of it to clean the blood.



There are many old roads starting from the main road and running through the district of Glentogher. There was an old road where some of the Carrowmore people carted in their turf from the hill. It led from Hon Hirl's and went eastward into the moss where the people cut their turf. It was used for carting turf until last year when a new one was made because the people made a complaint of having a bad one. First the road was only a cow lane. Then the banks fell in and the people flattened
(continues on next page)

metadata.Teacher:: An tSr. Sorcha A. Ní Dhómhnaill

4493784/4420492/4536211.title: The Bridge at Andersons
4493784/4420492/4536211.text: This is an old bridge leading from the Moville to the Terryrone road but the road is not now used only the part used as the avenue to Andersons House (Gulladuff House).  The bridge is very old but there is little or no tradition as to time or persons connected with its erection.

4493784/4419971/4536415.title: The Friar's Bridge
4493784/4419971/4536415.text: The Friars bridge is across the bridge Bredagh Glen river which leads from Bredagh Glen to Terryrone.  It is built of flat flags.  It is an old bridge and it is about eight feet high and about four feet wide.  On the Terryrone side of the river the brae is very steep.  It is about two and a half miles from the mouth of the river.The Friars bridge is very useful on a wet day for children to get across when they are coming to school and for people coming across to the shop also.  This bridge got the name of the Friars bridge because a Friar was drowned there long ago.  There are iron rails on each side of the bridge.  Some of the Terryrone people that are going to Moville on the bus come across the Friars bridge.

4493778/4419561/4536844.title: Proverbs
4493778/4419561/4536844.text:
There are very many old roads in the district   of Ballylawn. They were      made hundreds of years ago. They are really very old. The names of the roads  in our district are named in English and Irish. We heave two roads at the top called Cnoc-na-Seáin and Cnoc Breac. Then we have the old lane, the new road and the Ballylawn Road and finally we have near the plantation a very old path almost unnoticeable  to-day where priests  once said Mass many hundreds of years ago. The place is still to be seen and it stretches to a sheltered place with a mound supposed to be a Mass rock. In the hills of the district  we have two cairns. It was said   that the people in the surrounding district buried their relatives underneath these buildings of stones and to-day
(continues on next page)

4493778/4419566/4536850.title: Old Churchyards
4493778/4419566/4536850.text:
(continued from previous page)
the reason why Catholics and Protestants are buried in Cooley graveyard. Some Protestants are still buried in Cooley.



The local roads are namely; the Glencrow road, the Terrirone road, the Burntland road, the Cowan road and the Cooley road. There is a very old road leading from Barrs at the Burntland road to the Cooley road. This road is about 200 years made. It is not on the county. It is a right of way. Most of these roads were made during the famine period.The people broke stones on these roads at the rate of four pence per day. There is an old path from Ballylawn to McGroarty's at the Cooley road. The rivers were crossed by means of fords before the bridges were made. There is a ford in the river between the Glencrow road and Anderson's mill. the people drew their corn across the river a this ford to get
(continues on next page)

4493778/4419567/4536858.title: Local Roads
4493778/4419567/4536858.text:
(continued from previous page)
it threshed in Anderson's mill. This place is called the "Cow Loaning'. There was another ford in the river at the foot of Lynch's farm. The people drew their flax across the ford to get it scutched in the scutch mill which belonged to a man named Douglas. There is a mass path in a field on the side of the hill on James Doherty's farm in Terrirone. There is a flat rock at the head of this field called the "Altar Rock". This is where the people went to hear mass.



There are some very old roads in the district and they are still used. Some of the lanes and roads have names. The names of the lanes are "The Rodding', 'John's Lane" "Roberts Lane" "Cawan Road" and "Burnland Road".It is called John's lane because a man named John lived at the  end of it. The
(continues on next page)

4493792/4421020/4537011.title: Local Roads
4493792/4421020/4537011.text:
Local Roads.The local roads in our district are namely the Upper Road Lower Road Glen Road Drumawier Road Carrihue Road Middle Road Balleigha Road Warren Road Carrick Road Ballymacarter Road and the Church Brae.The Upper road runs from Moville to Shrove and the Lower road runs from Shrove through the village of Greencastle and connects with the Upper road about half way between Greencastle and Moville.The road connectin these two roads are Church Brae Pound road and the Middle road.A short road runs from the Lower Road to Greencastle Gulf Links known as Warren road.
(continues on next page)

4493786/4420330/4537961.title: Buying and Selling
4493786/4420330/4537961.text:
(continued from previous page)
tinkers, dealers in feathers and rags and men looking for rabbit skins and horsehair came around this district.The various coins gone out of use are, the fourpenny bit, the tenpenny bit and the double-florin.The names given to the different coins in the district are a make, a tanner, a bob, a quid and a banker.



The names given to the local roads are The Lecamy Road, The Shesgin Road, The Drumnagessan Road and The Mount Scourge Road. The Lecamy Road leads from Noone's Bridge to Drumaville Bridge. The Shesgin Road leads from Noone's Bridge to Gleneely. The Drumnagessan Road leads from Lecamy to Culdaff. The Mount Scourge Road
(continues on next page)

4540646/4421958/4540750.title: Local Toys
4540646/4421958/4540750.text:
(continued from previous page)
through the hole.This is the way to make a swiss. Get a bit of leather on tin and cut it very round, and cut little nicks out of it round the edge. Then put two holes in the middle of it, and put a string in and out between the holes. Then wind it up, and pull.This is the way to make a sling. Get a little bit of soft leather, and tie a bit of string to the both sides. Then put a bit of stone, or people pebble and when you are firing let go one of the strings. These toys are made when the nights are long.



There is a road leading from Buncrana to Carndonagh, and this road is called the main road. There is a road starts at Anaugh, and it runs into
(continues on next page)

4493796/4421498/4548470.title: The Carts They Used Long Ago
4493796/4421498/4548470.text: Long ago they used different kinds of carts from what they have now. The carts that had were slipe-carts made with two long shafts and a frame like a box. They would yoke the horse in it. This is the kind of carts they used.Plough;- Long ago they used wooden ploughs instead of iron ploughs. They used  to construct these ploughs themselves and  there are some of them still to be seen. Light Long ago;- Long ago they did not use lamps they utilised big long bits of fir which they found in the bog. The little children would hold these firs for the women when they would be sewing shirts.

4428100/4378049/4548860.title: Local Roads
4428100/4378049/4548860.text:
It is thought that the road leading to my house in made for about three hundred years. Long ago there was wood where this road now is and a path running through it. This road leads to Knockanore and to fountain church.In olden times it was a public road. Through Mr. Hunt's wood quite close to this school is a path leading to the local church. It is one of the few "mass paths" now in use. It is not certain when this passage was made. The road leading from Dunmoon across to this school is not long in existence. Formerly there was no road but a pathway called the "Grassy hill".
(continues on next page)



There are two old roads or mountain passes in the school district. Both were formerly roads and were much used up to fifty years ago when the present road was made. They are scarcely ever used now. One connects this district with the Yougal road at a place called the "Pike".A third old road is leading from Kilwinney to Ballymote which was one of the

4427887/4354535/4551477.title: The Local Roads
4427887/4354535/4551477.text:
There are a great many roads in this district.  The local names for them are the Mace road, Cultibo road, Cloonmore road, Curneen road, Popes road, Lodge road, Ballinamore road, Mourneen road, Common's road, Barnacarroll road, Carradine road, Derrylaha road, Bracloon road, Ballintaff road, Duck-street road, Horsefield road, Rodgers road, Kilcolman road, Kilhun road, Áró an Bhóchai road, and Walshes road.  These roads lead to different places throughout the district.  The Mace road leads through the Mace village.  The Cultibo road leads through the village of Cultibo.  The Cloonmore road leads from the village of Cloonmore on to Kiltimagh.  The
(continues on next page)

4427887/4354556/4551492.title: The Local Roads
4427887/4354556/4551492.text:
The names of the roads are, Cloonmore road, Claremorris road, Cultibo road, Popes road, Mace road, Ballinamore road, Balla road, Carradine road, Logatemple road, Derrylaken road, Cloogee road, Bóthar garbh, Bugawn road, Bracloon road, and Ballinataffy road.The pope's road leads from Mace road, to Cultibo road.  Cloonmore road leads from Claremorris road to Kiltimagh road. The mace road leads from the five croosroads to Barnacarroll.  Cultibo road leads from Pollagh road to Bracloon road.The Bracloon road leads from Cultibo road to Kiltimagh road. The Pollagh road is a very old road and it is still used. 4427887/4354564/4551497.title: The Local Roads
4427887/4354564/4551497.text:
There is a large number of roads in the district.  The names of the local roads are the Cultibo road, Cloonmore road, Pope's road, Curneen road, Mace road, Lodge road, Murtneen road, Commons road, Ballinamore road, Derrylahen road, Logatample road, Bóthar garbh, Ballintaffy road, Bracloon road, Duck-street road, Horse-field road, Rodgers road, Kilcolman road, Árdh an bhóair road and Walshes road.All the roads lead to different places.  The Cultibo road leads to Cultibo village.  The Cloonmore road leads through Cloonmore village and on to Kiltimagh.  The Pope's road leads on to the Cultibo road.  The Barnacarroll road leads to barnacarroll Church.  The Mace road
(continues on next page)

4427887/4354645/4552076.title: The Local Roads
4427887/4354645/4552076.text:
The names of the roads are, Cloonmore road, Cultibo road, Curneen road, Mace road, the Lodge road, Popes road, Horse-field road, and Rodgers road.Rodgers road and Horse-field road are the two oldest roads in the parish.Cloonmore road leads from Claremorris road to Derrylahen road.  The Murneen road leads from Kilcolman cross-roads to the Black-gates.  Derrylahen road leads from the end of the Cultibo road out to the Kiltimagh road.  Some of these roads are not used for traffic now.There are patches of old byways in the district yet.In the times of the famine

Tá a fhios ag an chuid is mó de na daoine thart annseo an fáth gur tugadh an t-ainm sin do'n bhealach; Pádruig Ó Cuinn, Loachmuice (72 bliadhna) d'innis domh é. Bhí sé ag obair ann agus é in a stócach nuair a bhí an bóthar a dhéanamh, fágann sin gur déanadh é timcheall 56 bl. ó shoin)27-7-34An Sagart Mac Aoidh, sagart paróiste ins na Gleanntaí a fuair déantaé, mar aithghiorra do mhuinntir Mín a' Chait, Mín a' Líneachain, agus Bealach na gCruach, fá choinne dul ag an Aifreann i mBaile na Finne. Ní raibh teach phobail ar bith ar an Éadan fá'n am.Ní raibh préataí ar bith ann an bhliadhan sin agus in áit airgif a thabhairt do na daoine bheireadh sé céad mine buidhe dóibh mar pháighe seachtmhaine, acht duine ar bith a bhí i bhfad ó'n tsiopa bheireadh sé an t-airgead do. Bhíodh a mhuinntir ag iomchur brocháin fá choinne a ndinnéara do'n bhunadh bhí ag obair, sin mar fuair sé a ainm.Bhí sé in úsáid i ndiaidh thógáil an teach phobail ar an Éadan agus bealach cairt maith ann go dtí an bhliadhan a tháinig an Tuile Mhór 1908 nó 1910. Tugadh ar shiubhal an dá dhroichead (ceann amuigh agus ceann istigh) agus níor deisiughadh an bóthar ó shoin.

4428339/4397103/4552286.title: Péist sa Loch
4428339/4397103/4552286.text:
Chonacthas i bhfad ó shoin peist san loch thíos ó'n sgoil seo - Loch Muice. Deir Conal Mac Suibhne gur chuala sé a athair a radh go bhfaca sé go minic é agus é óg. Níor facthas anois é suas le tríocha blian acht fá'n am sin chonnaic a lán daoine é agus bhí ionrádh mór ag duk thart fá dtaobh de. Druim ag éirghe os cionn an uisge - é an-mhór, an-dubh, gan ceann nó iorball air, cosamhail le eascon acht i bhfad ní ba mhó. Tá breac go flúirseach san áit anois.Conal Mac Suibhne, Loch Muice a thug an t-eolas sin damh.



Déanadh é timcheall 50 bliadhain ó shoin. An Sagart Mac Aoidh a fuair déanta é mar aithghiorra do mhuinntir Mín a' Chait, Mín a' Líneachain, agus Bealach na gCruach isteach ag an Teach Phobail i mBaile na Finne. Ní raibh teach phobail ar bith ar an Éadan fá'n am.Bheireadh sé céad míne buidhe in áit airgid in aghaidh na seachtmhaine don bhunadh bhí ag obair ann, sin mar fuair sé a ainm.Bhí bealach cairt ann an uair sin agus bhí go dtí an bhliadhan gur tháinig an Tuile Mhór 1908 nó 1910. Tugadh ar shiubhal an dá dhroichead; níor cóiriughadh an bealach ó shoin.Pádraig Ó Cuinn Loch Muice a d'innis. Bhí sé ag obair ann an t-am go raibh an bealach a dhéanamh.

4428339/4397302/4552320.title: Bealaí Móra na hÁite
4428339/4397302/4552320.text: Bealach an BhreacháinTosuigheadh ar sa bhliadhain 1881 agus sé an páighe a bhí as ná naoi bpighine sa lá agus tuileadh ag fagháil púnt míne buidhe sa lá.Bhí acu le bheith ag iomphur rarbhail i gcliabh le cur air. agus bhíodh siad ag obair ón seacht ar maidin go dtí a seacht tráthnóna. Giota beag aráin a bhíodh leobhtha fá choinne a ndinnéara. Sé an Sagart Mac Guidhe a chur ar bun é.Bealach MeenatamhaíBhí an garbhail le h-iomphur  i gcliabh acu, agus gheibheadh siad é ar achan taobh de'n bhealach mhór. Púnt míne buidhe sa lá an páighe a bhí acu.Ona seacht ar maidin go dtí an seacht tráthnóna a bhíodh acu le hoibriughadh.

Timcheall deich mbliainó shin agus bhí ar cuid de na daoine a dhul amach as na tighthe amach ar na boithre.Tá talamh mhaith timcheall na h-áite agus cuireann na daoine go leor barraí. 4566052/4562537/4569228.title: Boats on Lough Corrib
4566052/4562537/4569228.text:
THE EGLINTON  was the first steamer that sailed on Lough Corrib. It was bought by three landlords - Messrs. Staunton, Lynch, and Guinness and brought to Lough Corrib in 1862. It seems  that it did not pay its owners, and after about thirty years trading it was sold to a man from Killaloe. She traded on the Shannon but was drowned after a time.The St. PatrickSome years after the sale of the Eglinton the Lydons and Hessions who had been trading on the lake with sailing boats, united, bought timber and after having saved it they built it into a boat. This boat was called the St. Patrick. Patsy Hession was captain of the steamer, but on wild day, when delivering a load at Kilbeg his leg was caught between the boat and the quay and he was killed.The Fairy Queen. The Fairy Queen was
(continues on next page)

4562127/4561805/4569568.title: The Famine
4562127/4561805/4569568.text:
(continued from previous page)
The famine of the potato crop was so great in 449 that the clergy ordered people not to sow them anymore rather than waste that much seed. Notwithstanding that the people did so. They shook the small potato seed like the corn seed and there was never known since on before better potatoes than what there was that year.

4566063/4563706/4571635.title: The Roads in the District
4566063/4563706/4571635.text: The Roads in the DistrictAbout a mile from Barnaderg there is a stone bridge.  The place is called "Polla Chappall", because it is said that the horses belonging to the Mail Coach fell into a steep incline there one time.The roads went straight up from there for about one quarter of a mile and then turned came out again where there is a small bridge which is known as the "Droetachen" afterwards the main road was made.Maureen DolanBarnaderg,Ballyglunin.Martin Dolan,Barnaderg,Ballyglunin.

Tá crósaire déanta d'adhmuid ar an gcairn sin agus tá an cairn suidhte in-aice falla ar an mbóthar ó Gaillimh go Órán Mhór. 4566067/4564075/4572120.title: Old Roads
4566067/4564075/4572120.text: 31-3-38Old RoadsThere are many old roads round this town. There is one out in the Bally Mote road and it leads out to Joher. That road is not used now but the trace of it is still to be seen. The grass has grown over it now and it is not easy to notice it. There is also another old road leading through the palace and that was the road the people used to go to the fair green long ago. It was Harnells that owned it when the road was going through it. But when the protestant Bishop bought the palace the road was stopped going through it

63Old RoadsThe Kilclooney Road, The Bog Road, The New Line, and the Killure Road. The Kilclooney road leads from the The Line to Killure road. The New line leads from Ballinasloe to Ahascragh. The Bog road leads from the New Line to the Killure road. The Killure road leads from Killure Church to Ashe's Cross. The Gleann Dubh road leads from Derrymullen road to Bunn Abann bridge.There is a road leading from Killure road to Kilgerrill trunk road to the bog. The Lenafin road leads from Killure road to Moher. There is a bog road going into Fairfield and it is called "Jack's Road." There is also a

Q. Have you ever seen the Liffey dance?A. Yes! When the Lucan band crossed      the bridge!Q. Why is dancing not permitted in the       coffee house now?A. Because the last time the people      danced there, they 'took the floor'.

There were four tailors in Lucan about 40 years ago. Their names were Murray, O'Reilory, Jeeves, Vickory. Yes sometimes they travelled from house to house.  The Mill in Lucan wove cloth nearly every house in Lucan had a spinny wheel in front of the fire.  Bright clothes at weddings, black clothes and a black scarf and hat band at funerals.

4566072/4564517/4573675.title: Local Roads
4566072/4564517/4573675.text: The road leading from Loupark bridge to Gascana was made when Killoran land was divided in the year 1910. There was great traffic on it as it was leading to the bog. It was in a very bad condition until it was re-made in 1937. They made a very nice road of it and put a concrete bridge across the river.

4566077/4564976/4574014.title: The Local Roads
4566077/4564976/4574014.text:
The Local RoadsNear the village of Kilconnell, County Galway, there are many roads, but the best known road of them all is Bóthar na Sop.On this road, the bell of Kilconnell Abbey was carried away to be hidden, at the time that Cromwell's soldiers were steering their train of war on towards Kilconnel -  I suppose to destroy the Abbey, and murder the holy monks.  The bell was carried over Bóthar na Sop, and buried in Móin na Bráthar,It is supposed that one family near Kilconnell knows where the bell is hidden, but if they tell anybody the exact spot, their belief is that it will mean a certain death for a member of the family. I suppose this is handed down from sire to son.Another strange thing about this road is that it was the meeting place for all the youths from a few miles around.  Dancing was the general pastime.  There used to be fiddlers, pipers and many other
(continues on next page)
