5008905/4965598/5239052.title: The Blackhall Road
5008905/4965598/5239052.text:
On the way from Herbertstown to Ardcath there is the remains of a rampart in a field - the property of the McIvor family Heathtown. At the back of this rampart there is a road called the Blood Hill on the Black Hall. A battle was fought on a height on this road during the 17th century. The Irish forces were defeated - there fell in this battle a man named Kavanagh - a descendant of Art McMurrough Kavanagh. In a field along the Black Hall road there was found a number of skeletons, presumably the remains of those who fell in the Battle.



There was a married couple who had one child who was a long time lying in the cradle making no attempt to walk. One day John the husband was telling his wife Mary that he intended going to the local blacksmith to have a new spade made as he thought it time to plant some early potatoes. The child in the cradle overheard the remark. "Daddy" he said, "if he rubs his head after finishing the spade don't take it. It will be a bad one." "Why" says the father, "what
(continues on next page)

5008906/4965637/5239114.title: (no title)
5008906/4965637/5239114.text:
Years ago there were two men named Lamb and Duff hanged on Mullagh-telling for not being able to pay 5s.9d.Lily ByrneClinstownStamullen



There are two turn pike gates on the Stamullen - Gormanstown road where long ago everyone had to pay to get past.Thomas Murphyliving at present in England.

5008906/4965637/5239115.title: (no title)
5008906/4965637/5239115.text:
Years ago there were two men named Lamb and Duff hanged on Mullagh-telling for not being able to pay 5s.9d.Lily ByrneClinstownStamullen



There are two turn pike gates on the Stamullen - Gormanstown road where long ago everyone had to pay to get past.Thomas Murphyliving at present in England.

5008906/4965653/5239147.title: (no title)
5008906/4965653/5239147.text: The old road to Dublin was through the village of Gormanstown and the Mail Coaches used to go that way and get refreshments in the old inn at the Bridge Foot.Molly FlemingGormanstownCo. Meath.

5215813/5215349/5239277.title: Local Roads
5215813/5215349/5239277.text:
local roadsThere was an old woman who lived in leenavesta. Her name was Winnie Egan. She started a road in leenavesta and she made it to the river of loughta. She made about a mile of a road and she made it as good as any man. It is called the old road of Loughta. This woman lived about two hundred years ago1..6..38She was my great great grandmother Egan Egan Egan hundred hundred hundred
(continues on next page)

5215813/5215443/5239703.title: Old Roads
5215813/5215443/5239703.text:
Old roadsThere was an old road going from Loughty to Lennevesta. There was once a woman named Mrs Hastings and she got 4 a day for making the road. She got a cleeve and carried the stones and gravel on her back.The people say she made it as good as a man would make it. The people used cross the rivers in fords with their horses before bridges were made. If the river was too big for the horse they would have to go about a mile to another bridge and cross the river.
(continues on next page)

5236102/5232016/5240177.title: The Local Roads
5236102/5232016/5240177.text:
All the roads in this district are:- Gurtnaminch road, Ennismore road, Horgans road, Greenville road and there are two bog roads near my house.The Gurtnaminch road begins at about thirty yards from Killocrim National School and it ends at Patrick Enright's of Beenamilane. The Ennismore road begins at Harnette's railway gates and it ends at MrsHorgan's road begins at Horgan's cross and ends at Finuge bridge.The Greenville road begins at Markey's bridge and ends at scortley cross and the two bog roads lead from Gurtnaminch
(continues on next page)

5215813/5215509/5240252.title: Local Roads
5215813/5215509/5240252.text:
There is an old road going from my village over to DrumminIt was my grandfather made it It is still used.There is a road going from Tamnach Shlinneáin to Drummin and Westport.There was an old road going from Tamnach Shlinneáin to Lecanvey and Durless The people used to go that way when they used to go to Mass to Lecanvey and to the sea for sand and when they used to go to Westport
(continues on next page)

5236102/5232079/5240386.title: The Local Roads
5236102/5232079/5240386.text:
The road leading from Listowel to Ennis More is called the Greenville road. It runs straight from Listowel and comes to an end at Ennis More. The distance from Listowel to Ennismore where the road ends at Huson's gate would be about 3 1/2 miles. On the road from Listowel to Ennismore there are three cross roads. First the Convent cross leading to Ballybunion. The second is Scortlea cross leading on to Ballycondy and various districts. The third is Killocrim cross better known as Horgan's cross. It leads to Finuge and Lixnaw and by going on straight to Dromclough it will take you into Tralee. There are three by-roads
(continues on next page)

5235152/5222886/5240730.title: Old Roads
5235152/5222886/5240730.text: 18-10-1938There is an old road in Aran.  It is known as Bóthar Cillín. Long ago a Saint named Áran built a church beside this boreen.  It is from this church my native village gets its name, Killenaran.The Banshee's Path: There is a path leading through fields. The Ban-shee used to travell through these field during Summer evenings. She used to caoin or cry.

5235152/5223325/5241592.title: Old Roads and Bridges and Ruins
5235152/5223325/5241592.text: 1. There is an old boreen in Mulbrook Kilcolgan. It is called Boreen Aran for it is leading from Mulbrook to Aran. 2. There is an old Bridge below Denis Kelly's house which is in Aran Kilcolgan. There was a man passingit one night and bean-Sidhe followed him. He ran as fast as he could until he came to a house. the house was beside a Cross-Roads. The bean-Side could not go any further for it is said that the bean-side can never pass a Cross Roads. 3. For the making of roads long ago people were paid four pennies a day or a lb of yellow meal.

5236102/5232152/5241791.title: The Local Roads
5236102/5232152/5241791.text:
All the roads in this district are old: The Lane road, Gurtnaminch road, Ennismore road, Horgan's road and the Bog road.The Lane road begins at Holloran's cross and ends at the river Feale. It is about one hundred and fifty yards long. The Gurtnaminch road begins about thirty yards from the Killocrim N. S. and ends at John Horgan's house of Beenamilane. It is about two miles long.The Ennismore road begins at Holloran's cross and ends at Hewson's house. It is about three miles long. Horgan's road begins at Horgan's cross and ends at the Finuge
(continues on next page)

5236102/5232195/5241873.title: The Local Roads
5236102/5232195/5241873.text: The road leading from Listowel through Abbeydorney to Tralee is centuries old. In old times before trains were run the mail couch travelled that road carrying mail and passengers. Daniel O'Connell the Liberator travelled on this road to Dublin. The bog road which leads from the bog to the public road is very old. This road was made the time of the famine but it was repaired a few years ago. There is a mud fence across the river at "Praty" about five feet wide. This served as a crossing place in days gone by. There is an old public path leading from Ballyhorgan through Ballintogher and Ballyhennessy to the Clanduglas road.

5236102/5232234/5242014.title: The Local Roads
5236102/5232234/5242014.text: There are many roads in our district - Ballyhorgan road, the river road and Finuge cross where the people gather by night. Before the bridge was made the people used to go across the ford. There is a road there for this purpose. There is an old road going from the public road in to Hennessy Hellard field, but it is not used now.

5236102/5232286/5242234.title: The Local Roads
5236102/5232286/5242234.text: There are many roads in our district. the name of the road that crosses our houses is the male road Because they used to carry male in cars that (time) way before Back a bit of that road there is a road turning up and is called Ballyhorgan road  Because it is the first road turning off the public road

5236102/5232353/5242434.title: The Local Roads
5236102/5232353/5242434.text:
The main road from Listowel to Ennismore was got up by Mr. Hewson that lived in Ennismore. He gave this work to the men around. They were employed in it for several months. There are several names in that road the names are Greenville, Scotlea, Ennismore and Killocrim.In my district there are a number of old roads such as the Gerah, the Forge Road and the Clune road. The Gerah road leads into the Greenville bog. The Forge Road also leads into the Greenville bog. The Clune road leads into a marsh which is called Gurtanein. These roads are used yet.
(continues on next page)

5236102/5232418/5242556.title: The Local Roads
5236102/5232418/5242556.text: The road leaving from Listowel is going to Tralee and to Lixnaw. There is a road in Kellerhers land it is not being used for years. There is a mud fence across the river at "Praty" about five feet wide. This served as a crossing place in days gone by.

5236102/5232476/5242604.title: Local Roads
5236102/5232476/5242604.text: In the olden times the road that now leads to Ennismore turned off through the bogs near the railway-gates and at that time it was known as the monastry-road and the road can still be traced. It lead to the monastry in Ennismore and another ancient road ran from that to the Dysert churchyard, and then one to Rattoo the name of it was Boreen-dorca. In those days there was no river between Ennismore and Dysert and the road at each side of the river can be traced to this present day. Before Finuge bridge was built the people used cross the ford near Finuge. They used also cross the ford at Poulnahaha because there were no bridges in those days.

5236090/5230195/5242919.title: Seancheirdeanna
5236090/5230195/5242919.text:
(continued from previous page)
a living and so we have the proverb "working like a nailer." In the old days the people used wooden vessels called noggins instead of the delph ones we use to-day.



The "Stirabout" which starts near the Kiltimagh Balla road and goes accross Sliabh Cairn to Comderry is so  called because the pay the men got was a half hundred weight of yellow meal a week.
(continues on next page)

5236090/5230270/5243016.title: Folklore - Herbs
5236090/5230270/5243016.text:
(continued from previous page)
is good for worms in horses.



The "Stir-about" road starts off a bye road off the Kiltimagh - Balla road and ends at Craggagh cross-roads. It was so called because the men used get a stone of yellow meal a day as payment. Bóithín na Dóibhe goes from Lackafinna to the "Stir - about" road. It passed through land of díobh
(continues on next page)

5236090/5230301/5243051.title: Seancheirdeanna
5236090/5230301/5243051.text:
(continued from previous page)
Luke Lydon who used to make nails. He used not make much money as the work was slow and on that account he had to work hard. An old proverb is "working like a nailer."



The Stirrabout road which goes across Sliabh Chairn from Comderry to Ballinamore was made in the year 1891. It was given that name because the men who worked on the
(continues on next page)

5235172/5224443/5243188.title: Bóithre an Cheantair
5235172/5224443/5243188.text:
Déineadh bóithre sa pharróiste i n-aimsir an droch-shaoghal. Sé pighne sa lá a gheobhadh na fir a bhíodh ag obair ar an mbóthar. Bhíodh na mná ag obair ar an mbóthar. Níl sgéal na cúntas mar gheall ar dhéanamh bóithre. Bhíodh a lán casáin ag dul ón mbóthar mór gach áit.
(continues on next page)

5236090/5230326/5244139.title: Bóithre an Cheantair
5236090/5230326/5244139.text:
The stirabout road goes across Sliabh Chairn from Craggagh to Ballinamore and goes through Camdhoire  The payment for work on that road was a stone of  yellow meal every day on which they would work. There was a short cut from Balla to Boholo across Sliab Chairn.Long ago there was a man killed at a cross-roads
(continues on next page)

5236090/5230360/5244255.title: Herbs
5236090/5230360/5244255.text:
(continued from previous page)
Chicken weed grows on roofs of houses and it is a great cure for a sore neck. Broom grows in any sort of land and it is cure for heart disease. It is also a cure for freeing horses from worms.



The names of the roads that are in our district  are, the "Stirrabout" road, and the, "Baile na
(continues on next page)

5236090/5230385/5244285.title: Seancheirdeanna
5236090/5230385/5244285.text:
(continued from previous page)
carts, wheelbarrows, handbarrows, and wooden gates. The people used to do a lot of fishing and fowling and people burned their own lime. All the men could do their own thatching but that is not the case now.



The "corkscrew or Stirabout" road extends from Comderry across Sliabh Cairn to the main road between Balla and Kiltimagh. Cloch a Chaipín extends from
(continues on next page)

5236090/5230421/5260097.title: Seancheirdeanna
5236090/5230421/5260097.text:
(continued from previous page)
and thickened and were then fit for use. Out of this leather they sometimes made a seive which they used for winnowing oats. This leather was not used for making shoes.



The "Corkscrew" or "Stirabout" road extends from Comderry to the main road between Balla and Kiltimagh. When the Corkscrew road was being made, the pay given was a half a
(continues on next page)

5236090/5230476/5260184.title: Bóithre an Cheantair
5236090/5230476/5260184.text:
The "Stirabout" road which goes across Sliabh Chairn from Comderry to Ballinamore was made in the year 1891. It was given that name because the men who worked on the road got a stone of yellowmeal every day as payment instead of money. No women worked on the road. My
(continues on next page)

5236090/5230516/5260536.title: Luibheanna
5236090/5230516/5260536.text:
(continued from previous page)
purify the bloodBuacalán roots boiled in milk is a cure for jaundice. Buachaill a' tighe grows on the roofs of houses and is a cure for sore eyes.



The chief roads in my district is the Bog road which extends across Slíabh Chairn and joins the oxford road at Byrne's forge. Part of this road is the Baile na rósite road. The Stirabout
(continues on next page)

5236090/5230551/5260589.title: Seancheirdeanna
5236090/5230551/5260589.text:
(continued from previous page)

The Bog road goes through the bog from Comderry across Sliab Chairn
(continues on next page)

5235172/5225446/5260949.title: Bia na Seanaimsire
5235172/5225446/5260949.text:
(continued from previous page)
D'itidís feoil fo minic. Feoil úr a bhíodh acu. Gheobhfadh siad iasc ins an fhairrge. Ní cuimhin le daoine tae a theacht do an chéad uair. Ní bhíodh cupáin acu san am fadó acht saucpáin



Máigh-Mhuileann an t-ainm atá ar am bhaile a bhfuil mé in mo chónaí. Tá sé i bparóiste Acla agus i burúntacht Burrishoole. Tá cathrach trí teach ann anois agus bhí fíche naoi ann fadó. Tá tuí ar cuid des na tighe agus sclátaí ar cuid eile acu. Baisteadh Máigh-Mhuilinn air mar bhí muillean ann fadó. Tá go leor daoine os cionn seachtó bliain d'aois. Tá Gaeilge maith acu. Is féidir leo scéalta innseacht i mBéarla. Seo ainmneacha na sean daoine: Padruig Ó Sheóighte, Michéal Ó Gallchóbhair, Brighíd Ní Gallchóbhair, Michéal Ó Piotán, Áine Ní Gallchóbhair, Padruig Ó Gallchóbhair, Seosamh Ó Piotán, Siobhán Ní Phiotán, Áine Ní Sheóighte, Peadar Ó Sheóighte, Michéal Ó Giontaoi, Martán Piotán, Brighíd Ní Gallchóbhair, Áine Ní Piotán, Padruig Ó Gallchóbhair, Michéal Ó Piotán, Áine Ní Chonaic, Mairgheadh Ní Phiotán. Tá siad uilig ina gcónaí i Máigh-Mhuileann, Acaill, Gob a' Choire, Condae Mhaigh Eo, Éire. Tá a lán fothracha sean tighe san mbaile fós. Ba gnáthach le go leor daoine as an dul go dtí Ameirioca. Níor luadh ainm an bhaile le aon amhrán ariamh. Tá loch amháin ann ar a dtugtar Loch na Lachan Fiadhan mar bhíonn go leor lachain fiadhain ann.
(continues on next page)

5235172/5225448/5260950.title: Mo Cheantar Féin
5235172/5225448/5260950.text:
(continued from previous page)
le go leor daoine as an áit dul go dtí Ameirioca. Níor luadhad ainm an bhaile le aon amhrán ariamh. Tá loch amháin ann ar a dtugtar Loch na Lachan Fiadhan mar bhíonn go leor lachain fiadhain ann.



Níor deineadh boithre gan áit seo i rith an Droch Saoghail. Bhíodh casáin acu nuair abhíodh síad ag dul go dtí an Aifrinn. Chuala mé mó athair ag rádh gur cailleadh fear in aice an chasáin agus cuireadh alán cloch ar mullach achéile agus nuair abhíonn duine ag dul thar an áit cuireann  sé beannacht Dé le na anam. Bíodh casán eile aca nuair abhíodh síad ag dul
(continues on next page)

5235172/5225588/5261164.title: Mo Cheantair Féin
5235172/5225588/5261164.text:
(continued from previous page)
leór daoine ag dul go dtí Ameirioca fado. Nior luadhad ainm na h-áite i amhrán no i rádh am ar bith.Talamh bocht atá ann. Níl choill ar bith in mo cheanntar féin.Abhainn an Choire Dubh, Abhainn an Choire Laoth, Abhainn an Choire Beag, Abhainn beag, Abhainn Mhór, Abhainn an Fhiadáin Fhliuch. Sin iad na haibneacha atá in mo cheanntar féin. Loch Áinne, Loch Gheal, Loch na mBreach Caoich, Loch an Choire Dubh, Loch Beag, Loch Árd, Loc na Sligeana Dubha, Loc Mór, Loch na gCaoirigh Dubha. Sin iad na locha atá in mó cheanntar féin.

5260428/5251877/5261254.title: Roads
5260428/5251877/5261254.text: There were no roads in Ireland long ago.  There is a road in every district now.  Long ago there were paths where the roads are now.  When the roads were being made at first there were only four made.  They started at Tara.  One road was going north, one south, one east, and one west.  then roads were made from these four.  Now the country is covered with them.  The government pays men to keep them in good order.

5260385/5244809/5261257.title: Bóithre an Cheantair
5260385/5244809/5261257.text:
Seo ainmeacha na boithre thart ar Sruthar Bóthar Buidhe, Bóthar Dealgain, Bóthar Cille Meadhon agus Bóthar Átha Cinn, bóthar Cathar Lios Gráin, Bóthar na Beannachtan agus Bóthar De Clifford, Téigheann Bóthar Cille Meadhon go Cille Meadhon agus go Baile an Ródhbha. Téigheann Bóthar Buidhe go Gleann Coirb. Téigheann Bóthar Átha Cinn go  Áth Chinn agus go Gaillimh agus téigheann Bóthar Cathair Lios Gráin go Cathair lios Gráin agus go Tuam. Théigeadh bothar na mBeannachtan go Ross na dTrí Eala  ó Cnoc na Beannactan. Théigheadh bothar De Cliford trí na páirceanna go Dealgan ach tá
(continues on next page)

5260428/5251904/5261323.title: Roads
5260428/5251904/5261323.text:
Long ago there were no roads or bridges.  There were paths in every field.  They had no bridges, but instead they had stones crossing the rivers.  They had also beams of timber made to cross the river.  They had no roads but paths.  They had no cars and they had no need for roads.  When they wanted to go to market or any place they would go on horse-back.  There are roads and bridges in every part of Ireland now.  Roads are very plentiful in the townland of Killuran.  There is a road from Bodyke to Bradford.  There are some of the roads
(continues on next page)

5260428/5251979/5261438.title: Roads
5260428/5251979/5261438.text:
In olden times roads were different to what they are now.  They were very rough and narrow, as there were no cars then.  The men had to work very hard to make the roads.  They got very little pay.  Sometimes they only got one meal.  In making the roads they tried to avoid the rivers as much as possible this made the roads very hilly.  In places where they could
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252022/5261478.title: Roads
5260428/5252022/5261478.text:
There are many roads in this district.  There is a road called the line.  It is between Broadford and Bodyke.  There are many other roads leading from it.  There are two going to O.C.Mills, and one up the mountain.  There is one going to lower BallyMcDonell and one to Knock Breac and one to Carhurley.  There is a piller box at one of the crosses.  The road leading to the mountain
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252049/5261504.title: Roads
5260428/5252049/5261504.text: Some roads are not as good as others.  Killuran road is leading from the main road to Gurtatrassa.  The name which we call it is the by road. There is a kishick on this road.   It is not long since this road was made.

5260428/5252081/5261546.title: Roads
5260428/5252081/5261546.text:
Roads are very plentiful now.  The people had no roads only paths.  There bits of by-roads leading in and out of some places, but the people never repaired them.The people have good roads now leading from place to place.  The people keep them in good repair nowadays.  There are roads leading from district to district.  Those roads are called public road.Some of the roads are tarred, but long ago the people knew nothing about tar or
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252115/5261572.title: Roads
5260428/5252115/5261572.text:
7th April 1938RoadsThe roads long ago are not like the roads that are there now. They were made by the banks of rivers, because they could not make roads through mountains. They had short-cuts through fields Some of the roads have names. There is a road called the "line" because it is very straight There is a road called Killuran road. There is a road called Ballymacdonnell road. There are cross roads everywhere and the people gather to them every Sunday
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252151/5261705.title: Roads
5260428/5252151/5261705.text:
Roads are very plentiful nowadays. Long ago the people had no roads. They only had paths by the river banks, and through the forests and woods. When the Celts came to Ireland the began the making of roads in it. The roads around this district are called the bog road, and the line road.There is a great traffic on the line road. It is the main road from Broadford to Scariff. The bog road is a bye-road not very much used for traffic. It is the oldest made road here around. Some roads are
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252180/5261762.title: Roads
5260428/5252180/5261762.text: Long ago, when roads were first made, it was by the side of a river people made them. The reason why they made them along the banks of rivers was because they had bad ways of working and they could not make them against a hill.The roads around this place have different names. One road is called the Line, because it is very straight. Another road is called Killuran road. Another road is called Ballymacdonnell road because it is made through Ballmacdonnell. There were no bridges at that time. It was stepping stones that were across the river then.

5260434/5252518/5261959.title: Old Roads
5260434/5252518/5261959.text: Old roads23rd February, 1938.Long ago the old men and women used to work on the roads for four pence per day.  They worked on the road up a pass our house.

5260434/5252892/5262810.title: Old Roads
5260434/5252892/5262810.text:
34                 Old roads                   22 nd. February,1938. In the years of the famine the people were starving in this part of the country.The English Government got a road made about ten miles long so as that the people could earn money.They pay that(we) they got was two pence per day.When they used to get their money they used to go and buy Indian meal which was the only food that
(continues on next page)

5260488/5259215/5263149.title: The Famine
5260488/5259215/5263149.text:
(continued from previous page)
money made his way to America and never came back again.



There was no road going through the townlands of Farragans fifty years ago. There was an old bog road coming over the head of Farragans a bit. The people of Farragans had to carry everything they used from that old
(continues on next page)

5260385/5245227/5265397.title: Bóithre an Cheantair
5260385/5245227/5265397.text:
Tá sean-bóthar ag teacht ó Cnoch Mágh go Guirtín. Sé an t-ainm atá air Bóthar na gCorp. Bhíodh sidheóga ag teacht an bóthar sin fadó. Níl fhios agam an uair a rinneadh é. Níl sé in úsáid anois acht rinnneadh sé san droch-shaoghal. Tá bóthar eile i nGuirtín agus an t-ainm atá air Bóthar an Phortaigh. Tá sé ag dul go Cathair Mór acht níl sé in úsáid anois. Níl fhios agam cén páigh a fuair na daoine, acht bhí cuid de na mná ag obair ann. Níl aon sgéal futha.



(continued from previous page)
playing the flutes and all they could knock out of them was "King Edward has the ears of an ass".

5260445/5253310/5267531.title: Roads
5260445/5253310/5267531.text: 43                Roads.There is  a road going up past Thos Mc Mahons house ,Slieveanuibhear to Peter Clarks' .i was never taken in contract only the way they used only repair them themselves.                 There is another roads coming from Slieveanoir school and it stops in the middle of the mountain .it is said that the money got finished and that it was left unfinished .it was going to come out the public road at on Tullys but never did.

5009042/4980154/5274412.title: The Hangman's Tree
5009042/4980154/5274412.text:
There is an ancient tree known by that name. It is situated on the roadside between Ballinlough Crossroads and the Gate Lodge. It is believed in Cromwell's time priests were hung on the tree. The local people fear to pass it at night (Mrs Leavy Kilrush - 50 s)An ointment for "Scabs" used be made from daisy-roots; another ointment for yellow jaundice  was made from primroses. ( Fuair Liam Ó Miodhcháin, (12) an píosa seo ó n-a aíntín Mrs Bennett, Kilrush -70-)

The local roads in Kells are known by different names. There is a road leading to Callan which is called the Callan road.There are three more roads leading from Kells, one
(continues on next page)

There are various ways for going and doing thins in this big worldIn order to go through this country there are many roads to guide us which are very easy to travel on
(continues on next page)

metadata.Collector: Brigid Ní Leatlobhair, local name Brighidh Ní Lálúar

5275203/5271757/5277565.title: Local Roads
5275203/5271757/5277565.text:
Roads are vey plentiful throughout the world and therefore they are very useful too.The local roads of this district are steam-rolled roads.From the cross of historical Kells there are four different roads leading to four different placesThere is the Callan road which leads westward from the National School.About three-quarters of a mile from the School in the Callan direction there is a by-road called the Crab-Road or the Crab-Bosheen because there are a great many crab
(continues on next page)

metadata.Collector: Brigid Ní Longáin, alternative name Delia Long

5215784/5209739/5277757.title: Local Roads
5215784/5209739/5277757.text:
Tavanagh Road which is eastof this school is 1,000 years old. It leads from Bohola to Balla. It was the only approach to Balla from this direction until the famine years when the Prizon Rd. running from Ballyvary to Balla was made.It was on the Tavanagh Road that funerals went to Balla. The coffins were carried on ropes. This road is still used.Beside this road there were many boreens, which were very very bad namely:- the bun-buide boreen                  Drum Machra "                  Tavanagh   "                   Prizon  "                   Cregg  "
(continues on next page)

5215784/5210174/5278484.title: Roads
5215784/5210174/5278484.text:
There is a road from Ballina to Claremorris passing through this district. It was made about seventy years ago. It takes about twelve months to make four miles of a road. First there are two banks built up one on each side of the road. Next there is a coat of large stones put for a foundation.If the ground is soft there are whins or bushes put on it. There are whins
(continues on next page)

5275203/5271903/5278646.title: Games I Play
5275203/5271903/5278646.text:
(continued from previous page)
guessed, then the angels beat the devils.



Roads are very useful for leading people to various towns and places.Every road has a name of its own. Roads are usually called after the places they lead to.There is a main road leading, from the village of Kells to the town of Kilkenny, and it is called by
(continues on next page)

metadata.Collector: Máire de Paor, alternative name Mary Power

5260428/5252211/5278857.title: The Care of the Feet
5260428/5252211/5278857.text:
(continued from previous page)
twelve years of age. They never had sore feet. The boots they wore were very heavy.



7th April, 1938RoadsLong ago the people had very bad, hilly roads because there were not much cars then. The men worked very hard making these roads because they had to carry all the material on their backs and hands. They worked for one penny and one meal per day. All the old by-roads
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252284/5278893.title: Roads
5260428/5252284/5278893.text:
There are only two or three roads in this district. One is called the Line road, another is called the old road, and another is called the bog road. The Line road is the publice road from Scariff to Limerick. The old road is a small narrow road. There is not much traffic on it. It is almost the oldest road made. None of the roads here around are steam-rolled. The bog road is a road leading out in the mountain. It is a very bad and narrow road. There is a little bridge near our farm. Beside the bridge there is a cross cut into the dike.
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252366/5278939.title: Roads
5260428/5252366/5278939.text:
There are not many roads near our place. There is one big road and motors travel on it. There is another bye-road running near it. This bye-road is very old. Long ago when there were not many roads it was along this road the mail car went. There is a small bridge crossing the road and there is a cross cut in the dike. It is said a man was killed there long ago. There is an old road going out through
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252402/5278977.title: Roads
5260428/5252402/5278977.text:
Long ago there were no roads in the country like there are now. When the people wanted to go from place to place  through the country it was on horseback they went, because there were no roads in the country that time. It was near rivers they made those paths. There were no bridges in the country at that time, only stepping stones which were settled across the river. There were beams of timber crossing the rivers, after
(continues on next page)

5009123/4988734/5279009.title: The Custom Gap
5009123/4988734/5279009.text: I also heard my mother tell of the wall which now adjoins the Convent of Mercy Garden (and the street). When she was young (1875) it was called "The Dead Wall."  She wondered why and on making enquiries she was told that in the bad times two men were hanged from it.

5009123/4988734/5279010.title: The Custom Gap
5009123/4988734/5279010.text: I also heard my mother tell of the wall which now adjoins the Convent of Mercy Garden (and the street). When she was young (1875) it was called "The Dead Wall."  She wondered why and on making enquiries she was told that in the bad times two men were hanged from it.

5282418/5249154/5282437.title: Local Roads
5282418/5249154/5282437.text:
The names of the roads in my district are The New Line, The Old Cork Road, The New Road, Clogheen Road, Greenhill, and Burnfort Hill, Island Road, Gurtanelig Road, Toureen and Bottle Hill, Creamery Road, Castle Hill, Annalentha Road, Monaparsons, The Wood Road, Dromore Hill, The Mill Road, Clyda-Ville Road. All these Roads are by-roads or continuations of the Roads from Mallow to Cork. The New Line and New Road are the newest of these and the Old Cork Road is the Oldest. The Old Cork Road is not much used now, because all traffic is going on the New Line, because it is the shorter of the two and by far the best for all
(continues on next page)

5282418/5249232/5282485.title: Local Roads
5282418/5249232/5282485.text:
In this district the roads are named by the places they go through. The road going from Dromahane to Mallow is called the Mallow road. The road from Dromahane to Newberry is called the Newberry road. The road from Dromahane to Beeing is called the new line, the road from Pendy's cross to Kilpadder cross is called the chapel road. The road from Connells cross to Mallow is called the lower road. The road from Dromahane to Mourneabbey is called the upper road. Most of the roads in the district lead from crosses There are a number of crosses in this district. The new line
(continues on next page)

5282418/5249358/5282620.title: Local Roads
5282418/5249358/5282620.text:
The local roads are called by the name of the district through which they go and to where they lead. The Mallow road is so called because it leads to Mallow. The Cork road because it leads to Cork the Mourne Abbey road because it leads to Mourne Abbey. Many roads meet together in this district and they form a cross such asWe have Dromahane cross because four roads meet together there; one leads to Mallow and we call that road the Mallow road. We call another the low road because it is in the lower part of the village. The upper road is so called because it is in the upper part
(continues on next page)

5274069/5271511/5283060.title: Folklore - Old Roads
5274069/5271511/5283060.text:
14th June 1938Folklore In olden times the public roads of Ireland were no better than the lanes you see leading to and from the bogs, steads or country villages to day. All bye roads were only made about 8 or 90 years ago and them only lined out but from time to time there were repairs giving to them until they are what they are to day. There were not very good roads needed in them times for the parish could hardly boast of two
(continues on next page)

5275203/5272027/5283468.title: Games I Play
5275203/5272027/5283468.text:
(continued from previous page)
and give it to some one else by a tip of a hand and so on.



There are various ways for going and doing things in this great world.In order to go through this country or any other country, there are many roads to guide us and are easy to travel on.There is a
(continues on next page)

5275203/5272224/5283533.title: Local Roads
5275203/5272224/5283533.text:
In Ireland the roads are well kept by the county counsils In all remote places and sea-shores the lonely life of the peasants is cheered by good roads.There were very bad roads in  and around Kells.Firstly men were imployed to clean the roads of all kinds of dirt.Then men came
(continues on next page)

5275203/5272339/5283577.title: Local Roads
5275203/5272339/5283577.text:
My house is situated about two hundred yards from Kells and a great many roads are scattered near it.The main road from Kells to Kilkenny is leading along by my house. About six years ago this road was in very bad repair.When the County Council saw this they set their strong men at the hard task of road-
(continues on next page)

5275203/5272439/5283607.title: Local Roads
5275203/5272439/5283607.text:
A great many of the roads in Kells are very ancient.For instance, the "Inish Snag" road, which leads from Kells to "Inish Snag".It is very ancient.It was used very much in the old days, but very little traffic goes on it now.There is a main road called the Kilkenny road, it is a very busy road.It goes from Kells to Kilkenny.There is another
(continues on next page)

5275203/5272501/5283781.title: Local Roads
5275203/5272501/5283781.text:
The roads around this district are known by special names.Most of these roads are known by the names of the places to which they lead.In Kells there is a large Cross from which four roads emerge.The one going west is known as the "Creamery Road" because this building is situated on it.This road also leads to the town of Callan.The road which
(continues on next page)

5275203/5272556/5283898.title: Local Roads
5275203/5272556/5283898.text:
Around this district there is a great many roads.The road leading from my home to Kells is called the Carrick road.This road is so called because it is the main road to Carrick town.The is a cross road in Kells and there are four roads leading to diffrent directions.One of those roads derives its name the "Creamery road", from a creamery which is situated on it.There is another road called the church road because it leads to an old church.There is another road
(continues on next page)
